legal_source: Travelers Insurance Company of Canada - Home Warranty Schedule E-1

what_covered: All defects in Materials and Labour
1_year_materials_labor.example_finding: Outlet not working, drywall cracks, paint defects

what_covered: Gas, electrical, plumbing delivery and distribution systems
Heating, ventilation, and air conditioning systems
Exterior cladding, caulking, windows and doors (if causing detachment or material damage)
Any defect rendering home unfit to live in
Non-compliance with Building Code (if creates health/safety risk)
2_year_systems.example_finding: Non-working furnace, water leak at window, electrical panel issue

5_year_building_envelope.example_finding: Roof leak, water damage from exterior, building envelope failure

what_covered: Structural Defects in Materials and Labour
Failure of Load Bearing parts (foundation, beams, posts, load bearing walls, floor/roof support)
Structural damage materially affecting residential use
10_year_structural.example_finding: Foundation crack, settling causing structural concern

covered: Water lines, drain systems, delivery/distribution systems
Foundation, load bearing components, structural damage
Cladding, windows, doors causing water intrusion
not_covered: Landscaping, grading, surface drainage (except Building Code required)

exclusions: Normal wear and tear, weathering, deterioration
Damage caused by owner, third party, or improper maintenance
Acts of nature (fire, flood, earthquake, etc.)
Damage to personal property or real property not part of home
Non-Building Code compliant work by non-builders
Insects/rodents (unless from non-compliance with Building Code)

common_property.limit: Lesser of: total contract price, $100k × unit count, or $2,500,000

claim_process: 1. Discover defect and assess if it falls within coverage period
2. Give written notice to Builder and Travelers (required before expiry)
3. Travelers will arrange inspection of the defect
4. If claim valid, Travelers covers repair or issues payment
5. All repairs warranted against defects until later of: 1 year or remaining warranty

key_definitions.defect: Design or construction contrary to Building Code OR requires repair due to Builder negligence
key_definitions.building_envelope: Assemblies separating interior from exterior, protecting from weather
key_definitions.load_bearing: Foundation systems, support beams/posts/columns, load bearing walls, floor/roof support
key_definitions.material_damage: Damage materially and adversely affecting residential use
key_definitions.structural_defect: Defect causing failure of Load Bearing part affecting Load Bearing function
key_definitions.readily_accessible: Available for visual inspection WITHOUT moving property, dismantling, or risk to persons

covered: Is a non-working furnace covered? → YES (2-year systems coverage)
Is water leaking through the roof covered? → YES (5-year building envelope coverage)
Is a foundation crack covered? → MAYBE (10-year structural, but depends on severity)
not_covered: Is window condensation covered? → NO (normal wear and tear exclusion)
Is a light fixture replacement covered? → NO (fixtures are excluded)
Is foundation settling 1/4 inch covered? → NO (normal settling excluded, must materially affect use)
needs_evaluation: Is a small drywall crack covered? → DEPENDS (if structural, yes; if cosmetic, no)
Is water in basement covered? → DEPENDS (if from defect, yes; if from flooding, no)

response_templates.covered: This issue IS covered under your **{warranty_type}** warranty. Specifically, {coverage_period} covers {what_covered}. Here's how to claim: {claim_steps}
response_templates.not_covered: This issue is NOT covered under your **{warranty_type}** warranty because it falls under the exclusion: {exclusion_reason}. This is considered {what_it_is} which is owner responsibility.
response_templates.partial: Part of this issue MAY be covered. {covered_part} is covered under {coverage_period}. However, {not_covered_part} is NOT covered because {reason}.
response_templates.requires_evaluation: Whether this is covered depends on professional evaluation. {basic_answer} To determine coverage, you should: {next_steps}
